The first day went well despite challenges she said, thanking staff for working hard to prepare schools and classrooms for social distancing and education in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Masks were a non-issue among students and teachers on the first day. All but two students at the seven sites Mrs. Gaylord visited on Tuesday reported to school with a mask. Extra masks are always available for students who forget theirs, she shared.

"I kind of like (the mask)," said Stuart Middle School student Sam McCullough. The 13-year-old said he was glad to be back in school.

TCPalm - Students across the Martin County School District have returned to campus for the first time since March, when schools first closed because of the Coronavirus pandemic. It was a first day of school unlike anything anyone had ever seen before, said Superintendent Laurie J. Gaylord.

The first day went well despite challenges she said, thanking staff for working hard to prepare schools and classrooms for social distancing and education in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Masks were a non-issue among students and teachers on the first day. All but two students at the seven sites Mrs. Gaylord visited on Tuesday reported to school with a mask. Extra masks are always available for students who forget theirs, she shared.

"I kind of like (the mask)," said Stuart Middle School student Sam McCullough. The 13-year-old said he was glad to be back in school.

"It's better with the teacher in front of you," he said. "She can repeat (instructions) multiple times." #ALLINMartinüëä

Q: If I elect to have my child participate in the traditional, in-person school option, will they be able to ride the bus to and from school?

A: Yes. Students who are eligible for school bus transportation as defined in School Board Policy 8600 will continue to be eligible to ride the bus. To be eligible for transportation, students must live more than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school OR be eligible for transportation due to a documented hazardous walking condition (as defined in Chapter 1006.23, Florida Statutes). On February 18, 2020, the Martin County School Board voted to eliminate the seats available and grandfathering programs that previously allowed students who lived less than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school to be eligible for transportation.

All designs and wording present on masks must adhere to the dress code regulations found in the District‚Äôs Code of Student Conduct. Staff and visitors will be required to wear masks when social distancing is not practical or possible.

Isolation protocol: Anyone who has tested positive for COVID-19, anyone who has symptoms of COVID-19 and is able to recover at home, or anyone who has no symptoms (asymptomatic) but has tested positive for COVID-19- must isolate themselves.

Q: If I elect to have my child participate in the traditional, in-person school option, will they be able to ride the bus to and from school?

A: Yes. Students who are eligible for school bus transportation as defined in School Board Policy 8600 will continue to be eligible to ride the bus. To be eligible for transportation, students must live more than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school OR be eligible for transportation due to a documented hazardous walking condition (as defined in Chapter 1006.23, Florida Statutes). On February 18, 2020, the Martin County School Board voted to eliminate the seats available and grandfathering programs that previously allowed students who lived less than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school to be eligible for transportation. Please join us in congratulating Martin County High School senior Megan Krevitz!

"Megan started high school participating in the Culinary Academy and OPUS Choir, which she loved," proud mom Tammi Krevitz shares. "She's also participated in the Martin County 4-H program for the past 7 years, showing various animals. Megan's pretty easy going (even after getting up well before school to drive 20 miles round trip to check on her fair project for 5 mths), with an infectious laugh and sense of humor her family loves. She's known for years she wants to be in culinary, preferably baking.
